WGET is a popular command-line tool used for downloading files over the internet. It supports various protocols including HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, and even Metalink. The software is available for various platforms including Windows, macOS, and Linux.

In this article, we will take a closer look at WGET, its features, and how to use it for downloading files.

## Features

WGET comes with a variety of features that make it a powerful and reliable tool. Some of its notable features include:

### Recursive Download 

WGET can automatically download all the files and subdirectories within a directory, making it ideal for downloading large directory structures. 

### Resuming Interrupted Downloads 

WGET can resume interrupted downloads, which means you can stop the download process and continue later without starting from scratch.

### Mirroring Websites 

WGET can be used to mirror entire websites. This feature is helpful when you need to archive a website for offline use.

### Proxy Support 

WGET supports various types of proxies, including HTTP, HTTPS, and FTP proxies.

### User-Agent Customization 

WGET allows you to customize the User-Agent header used in requests to a website. This feature can be useful when you need to bypass restrictions such as anti-bot mechanisms.

## Installation

WGET is available for download on various platforms. You can download the software for your platform from the official website at https://www.gnu.org/software/wget/. 

Once you have downloaded the software, follow the installation instructions provided on the website.

## Basic Usage

Using WGET is straightforward. Here is an example of how to download a file using WGET:

```
$ wget https://example.com/file.zip
```

This command will download the file.zip file from the website example.com.

## Conclusion 

WGET is a powerful command-line tool for downloading files over the internet. Its various features make it a versatile tool that can be used for various purposes including downloading large directory structures, mirroring websites, and resuming interrupted downloads. 

If you havenâ€™t used WGET yet, we encourage you to give it a try for your next file download.
